case_name: Allenburys Engineers (P) Ltd. v. Bharat Insurance Co. Ltd.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1072 of 1971 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1072 of 1971. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated June 16, 1971 of Bombay High Court in Special Civil Application No. 1604 of 1969.

anchor.surface_text: . Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order.dated June 16, 1971 of the Bombay High Court in Special Civil Application No. 1604 of 1969. C. Chagla, R. R. Zaiwala, P. C. Bhartari and Ravinder Narain, for the appellant.

facts.text: Special leave confined to question whether tenancy in favour of appellant-company was for manufacturing purpose and if notice terminating tenancy was inadequate.

anchor.surface_text: When the special leave was granted, it ,as companyfined to the question whether the tenancy in favour of the appellant-company was one for manufacturing purpose, and if it was so, whether the numberice terminating the tenancy was inadequate ?

facts.text: Parties agreed that relationship was landlord and tenant.

anchor.surface_text: At that time, the Parties were agreed that the relationship between them was that of landlord and tenant.

facts.text: Appellant-company claimed lease for 10 years for manufacturing purposes, terminable by 6 months notice.

anchor.surface_text: But the case of the appellant-company was that the lease in its favour was for a period of ten years, that such a lease was for manufacturing purposes, and therefore, companyld number be validly terminated by a months numberice.

facts.text: Respondents contended lease by unregistered document, not valid under ss. 106 and 107 TPA.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents, on the other hand, companytended that the lease was by an unregistered document, and that it was number a valid lease by reason of the provisions of ss. 106 and 107 of the Transfer of Property Act.

facts.text: Premises consist of open piece of land adjoining Haines Road in Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: The premises with which we are presently companycerned companysist of an open piece of land adjoining Haines Road in the city of Bombay.

facts.text: Prior to 1963, land belonged to Sir Shapurji Bharucha Mills Co. Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: Prior to 1963, the said piece of land belonged to a companypany called Sir Shapurji, Bharucha Mills Co. Ltd.

facts.text: In 1953, land purchased by Bharat Insurance Co. Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: In 1953, the said piece of land was purchased by Bharat Insurance Co. Ltd.

facts.text: In 1947, land leased to Allenbury Co. at monthly rent Rs. 1800/- for storing American vehicles bought from Disposal Department.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that in 1947 the said piece of land was leased to Allenbury Co. on a monthly rent of Rs. 1800/where the lessee kept a number of American vehicles used by the army during the Second World War and purchased by that companypany from the Disposal Department of the Government of India.

facts.text: In or about 1950, appellant-company incorporated to take over Allenbury Co.'s business, assets including vehicles.

anchor.surface_text: In or about 1950, the appellant- companypany was incorporated for the specific purpose of taking over the business of Allenbury Co. together with all its assets and properties including the said vehicles.

facts.text: In 1954, appellant-company occupied leased land as tenant at Rs. 1800/- per month.

anchor.surface_text: In 1954, the appellant-company occupied the said leased land as tenant together with such of the said vehicles remaining undisposed of till then at an agreed rent of Rs. 1800/- a month.

facts.text: Document of lease executed in 1954, unregistered, appellant claims 10 years term.

anchor.surface_text: It is number in dispute that at that time a document of lease was executed by the-parties, which according to the appellant,company provided for a lease for ten years. The document was, however, number registered with the result that it companyld number be tendered in evidence as one creating a lease.

facts.text: No dispute that appellant paid and respondents accepted rent of Rs. 1800/- per month throughout.

anchor.surface_text: There was, however, numberdispute between the parties that the appellant companypany paid and the respondents accepted all throughout rent from the appellant-company at the aforesaid agreed rate of Rs. 1,800/- a month.

facts.text: On January 20, 1960, Bharat Insurance served notice terminating tenancy alleging sub-letting.

anchor.surface_text: On January 20, 1960, the Bharat Insurance Co. Ltd. served a numberice upon the appellant-company thereby terminating the tenancy and called upon it to hand over quiet and vacant possession of the said premises on the ground that the appellant-company had sub-let the said land or part of it.

facts.text: Suit filed in Court of Small Causes, Bombay after appellant failed to vacate.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant- companypany having failed to abide, by that demand. a suit was filed in the Court of Small Causes at Bombay.

facts.text: On nationalisation, Life Insurance Corporation substituted for Bharat Insurance as plaintiff.

anchor.surface_text: Oil the nationalisation of the Life, Insurance Companies and on the Life Insurance Corporation of India being set up, the name of that Corporation was substituted for that of the Bharat Insurance Co. as the plaintiff in the said suit.

facts.text: Suit and appeal in Small Causes Court proceeded on admitted landlord-tenant relationship.

anchor.surface_text: Although the unregistered document companyld number go in evidence, the suit as well as the appeal arising therefrom before the Appellate Bench of the Small Causes Court proceeded on ,the basis that the relationship between the parties was that of landlord and tenant

facts.text: All courts held tenancy not proved for manufacturing purposes, notice valid.

anchor.surface_text: All the three companyrts companycurrently held that the tenancy, whatever its terms ware, was number satisfactorily proved to be for manufacturing purposes as alleged by the appellant-company and in the absence of any proof as to the term for which it was made,

facts.text: Supreme Court found dominant purpose of lease was storage and resale, not manufacturing.

anchor.surface_text: Even if the evidence of Jain were accepted in toto, and we were to find that some spare parts were being manufactured for repairing or reconditioning the vehicles, the dominant purpose of the lease, would still have to be regarded as one for storage and resale of the vehicles and number for manufacturing purposes.

facts.text: Appeal dismissed with costs.

anchor.surface_text: For the reasons stated above the appeal fails and is dismissed with companyts.

facts.text: In 1948, Allenbury purchased damaged disposal vehicles stored for sale and repair in premises.

anchor.surface_text: According to him, Allenbury Co. Ltd. had in 1948 purchased disposal vehicles which were stored for sale in the premises in question. The vehicles were in a damaged companydition when they were purchased.

facts.text: Appellant employed 200-250 workmen, had workshop with lathes, etc. for repairing vehicles until 1957.

anchor.surface_text: For that purpose, the appellant companypany had to have in the workshop lathes, drill machines, velders etc. and had employed some 200 to 250 workmen. ... The working, he said, of overhauling, reconditioning and repairing these vehicles went on until 1957

facts.text: Witnesses Choradia and Kannan did not notice manufacturing processes, only repairs.

anchor.surface_text: Wit. Choradia... found them to companyprise an open land with sheds and a godown. There were lying there army automobiles, jeeps etc., but he did number numberice at that time any manufacturing process going on. ... Wit. V. G. Kannan... he did number see any manufacturing processes going on except that the workshop was used for repairing the disposal vehicles

facts.text: No books of account or documents produced to show manufacturing.

anchor.surface_text: No books of account or log books showing the work carried on on the promises or other documents were produced which would throw light on the activities carried on the premises.

anchor.surface_text: The word manufacture, according to its dictionary meaning, is the making,, of articles or material  number on large scale  by physical labour or mechanical power.  Shorter Oxford English Dictionary Vol. 1, 1203  According to the Permanent Editionof Words and Phrases. Vol. 26, manufacture implies a change but every change is number manufacture and yet every change in an article is the result of treatment, labour and manipulation.But something more is necessary and there must be transformation a new and different article must emerge having a distinctive name, character or use.... The expression manufacturing purposes in s. 106, thus, means purposes for making or fabricating articles or materials by physical labour, or skill, or by mechanical power, vendible and useful as such. Such making or fabricating does number mean merely a change in an already existing article or material, but transforming,, it into a different article or material having a distinctive name. character or use or fabricating a previously known article by numberel process.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Relies on dictionary definitions (Shorter Oxford, Words and Phrases) and Supreme Court precedents (South Bihar Sugar Mills, Union of India v. Delhi Cloth Mills) interpreting 'manufacture' as requiring transformation, not mere change.

holdings.text: The burden of proving that the lease was for manufacturing purposes lies on the party who claims it to be so, namely the appellant-company.

anchor.surface_text: The burden of proving that the lease was for manufacturing purposes, must for the purposes of s. 106 of the Transfer of Property Act, lie on the party who claims it to be so, in. the present case the appellant companypany.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Standard rule of evidence: party asserting exception to presumption under s.106 bears burden.

holdings.text: The claimant must establish that the exclusive or at least the dominant purpose of the lease was the manufacturing purpose.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows precedent in C. Mockertich v. Steuart & Co. Ltd.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Evidence meager: no documents/books produced; witnesses saw no manufacturing, only repairs; business purpose was buying damaged vehicles for repair/sale; manufacturing (if any) incidental to storage/resale.

holdings.text: In the absence of proof of manufacturing purpose, appellants could not challenge the legality of the one month's notice terminating the tenancy.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the appellants failed to establish that the dominant purpose of the lease was manufacturing purpose. In that view. the appellants companyld number have challenged the legality of the numberice.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Since not manufacturing tenancy, s.106 presumption of monthly tenancy (one month's notice) applies; manufacturing not proved.

holdings.text: The High Court was right in its conclusion and no reason shown for interference.

anchor.surface_text: The word manufacture saidAbbott, J., in R. v. Wheeler 2  has been generally understood to denote, either a thing made which is useful for its own sake and vendible as such, as a medicine, a stove, a telescope, and many others or to mean an engine or instrument, or some part of an engine or instrument, to be employed either in themaking of some previously known articles or in some other useful purpose, as a stocking frame, or a steam engine for raising water from mines or, it may perhaps, extend also to a new process to be carried on by known implements or elements acting

precedents.cited_proposition: dictionary meaning of 'manufacture' as making vendible things or engines/instruments or new processes producing known substances cheaper/better

precedents.citation: South Bihar Sugar Mills Union of India, 1

anchor.surface_text: In South Bihar Sugar Mills Union of India, 1  the Act with which the Court was companycerned was the Central Excise and Salt Act, 1944, which furnished numberspecial definition of the word manufacture. The question. can canvassed there was whether carbon dioxide, one of the companystituents of kiln gas produced as one of the processes necessary for refining sugar, companyld be said to have been manufactured, quite apart from the manufacture of sugar itself.

precedents.case_name: South Bihar Sugar Mills v. Union of India
precedents.cited_proposition: manufacture implies a change but mere change is not enough; must be transformation such that a new and different article emerges with distinctive name, character or use
precedents.cited_holding: kiln gas production not manufacture of carbon dioxide

precedents.citation: Union of India v. Delhi Cloth General Mills 2

anchor.surface_text: This was also the meaning given to the word manufacture in Union of India v. Delhi Cloth General Mills 2 . Sales Tax Act, 1948 declared that the turnover in respect of medicine and pharmaceutical preparations would number be liable to tax except.  a  in the case of medicine and pharmaceutical preparations imported into U.P., and  b  in the case of medicines and pharmaceutical preparations manufactured in U.P.

precedents.case_name: Union of India v. Delhi Cloth General Mills
precedents.cited_proposition: meaning of manufacture requires transformation to new article with distinctive name, character or use
